spolien.name: Small city hall portal

thumbnails.thumbInfo: Steel engraving by Gray and Laeisz, prior to 1842

spolien.titleInfo:
Date: 1649
Material: Sandstone

The arch of the small city hall portal is not quite three metres high. In comparison to other portals around the museum, it seems rather nondescript. The only original elements preserved are the two lions in the spandrels and the city coat of arms.
spolien.detailedInfo:
The portal, dating back to the year 1649, originally belonged to the extension of the old Hamburg city hall at Trostbrücke and it led to the premises of the Hamburger Bank. The city’s money reserves in the form of silver bars were stored in the vaulted cellar immediately to the left of the small city hall portal - until they were confiscated by the French occupying forces in the winter of 1813/1814. The portal survived the destruction of the city hall during the Great Fire of 1842. Later incorporated into the Old Johanneum on Domplatz, the portal was finally moved to the present museum building.

The museum’s architect, Fritz Schumacher, conceived an additional special feature: protected behind a glass frame, a so-called standard clock was installed in the now empty arch. A similar very accurate timepiece had been operated at this location even before the museum existed, namely when the Hamburg Observatory was still located at Holstenwall. The observatory featured a time station, which had also been reinstalled in the new museum. In this way, not only the standard clock, visible from the forecourt, was kept running until 1943, but also the tower clock on the museum roof.

spolien.name: Large city hall portal

thumbnails.thumbInfo: View of crane, exchange, city hall in 1842

spolien.titleInfo:
Date: 1601
Material: Sandstone

The large sandstone portal in the guild hall of the museum is over three-and-a-half metres wide and close to seven metres in height. It may come as a surprise, but this was the less prominent of the two main entrances to the old city hall at Trostbrücke.
spolien.detailedInfo:
The entrance belonged to an extension built 1601, which was attached to the right of the medieval building. Originally, upon entering the portal one first walked down a hallway to the council chamber and registry. Only a few remnants have been preserved of the portal, which had been renovated many times.

On the city hall portal in the guild hall of the museum, one can discover fluted Corinthian columns. Women carrying wreaths and palm branches in the arch spandrels symbolise peace. Above them are spear-carrying soldiers and lions holding the city coat of arms in a medallion. In the centre, above the medallion, the portal is crowned by another female figure serving as an allegory of peace. 
All in all, this pictorial programme could describe the state of affairs in Hamburg at the beginning of the 17th century: that of a prosperous city that relies on peaceful trade, but which also knows how to defend itself against attempted foreign interference. Both hope and advice to its inhabitants and visitors.

spolien.name: Emperor figures from the old city hall at Trostbrücke

thumbnails.thumbInfo: and city hall portal in Johanneum, 1894

spolien.titleInfo:
Date: 1602-1649
Material: Sandstone

Between the windows on the north-west side of the museum are 14 stone figures. They are statues of medieval German emperors, which were installed in a very similar way on pedestals on the facade of Hamburg’s old city hall at Trostbrücke until 1842.
spolien.detailedInfo:
Originally, 21 statues had been placed at the facade of the old city hall – seven each on three floors. Almost all of them survived the Great Fire, in which the building was not entirely destroyed. At least 20 of these statues could be reused in the construction of the new museum building. Six of these are lost today, as the building was badly damaged during the air raids of the Second World War.

Each of the emperors wear armour and a crown, orb, sword or sceptre to signify their power. Of the sceptre only the handles have been preserved. When situated at their former location, they embodied a special message: the city’s loyalty as a Free Imperial City lay solely with the German Emperor and not the Danish King, against whom this message was directed. Over time, the emperor figures became a kind of landmark in the city, evidenced by the erection of their successors on the new city hall in 1897.

spolien.name: Portal arch - Residential building on Katharinenbrücke 4

thumbnails.thumbInfo: ‘To God alone be the glory’, museum courtyard

spolien.titleInfo:
Date: ca. 1700
Material: Sandstone

The arch and its counterpart on the other side of the building originally belonged to a double portal of a residential building that stood on Katharinenbrücke until its demolition in 1907.
spolien.detailedInfo:
Both arches feature the depiction of a chubby-faced boy wearing a turban-like headdress. At the time of the house’s construction and its architectural decoration towards the end of the 17th century, black people were often depicted in this manner. Perhaps the immediate proximity of the house to St. Catherine’s Church plays a role here, as St. Catherine of Alexandria was sometimes worshipped together with St. Maurice, who was usually depicted as a turban-wearing black king.

It is not known, however, if black people from Hamburg served as models for the ornamental figures. At that time, some black people did live in the city of Hamburg, as its merchants were active in colonial trade. Children who had been abducted and enslaved worked as household servants here. In a painting by Johannes Voorhout in the museum’s collection, a black boy is depicted as a servant for a music-making social gathering centred around the musician Johann Adam Reincken. Reincken was the organist at St. Catherine’s Church and lived nearby.

spolien.name: Portal from the Spinnhaus on the Alster

thumbnails.thumbInfo: Portal from the Spinnhaus on the Alster
with the workhouse and poorhouse, watercolour, 1835
Spinnhaus after the Great Fire of 1842

spolien.titleInfo:
Architect: Hans Hamelau
Date:  1666-1674
Material: Sandstone

The portal from the old Hamburg Spinnhaus prison is now incorporated into the west facade of the museum. Until its destruction in the Great Fire of 1842, the Spinnhaus was located at what is currently the corner of Alstertor and Ferdinandstraße, i.e. somewhat to the left of the present-day Thalia Theatre.
spolien.detailedInfo:
Together with the neighbouring workhouse and penitentiary, the Spinnhaus was one of Hamburg’s premodern prison buildings. It was built between 1666 and 1674. As its name implies, the inmates mainly had to spin wool. Its prisoners were mainly prostitutes, who were to be resocialised through work. The Spinnhaus and its affiliated church were built with money left by the city councillor Peter Rentzel in his will in 1662.

He is commemorated by the Latin inscription above the arch: “Ex ultima voluntate et dispositione Dni. Petri Renzelii piae memoriae (According to the last will and testament of Mr Peter Rentzel of blessed memory) … in honorem Dei et flagitiosorum emendationem hoc ergastulum sumptibus ipsius exstructum est (… this workhouse has been built at his expense for the glory of God and the correction of evildoers).” According to the views of the benefactor, constant prayer and work would contribute to the purification of the prisoners. Rentzel thus posthumously erected in his name a further monument to a life pleasing unto God. During his lifetime, he had already generously donated funds for the renovation of Hamburg’s church towers.

spolien.name: Portal - Residential building on Speersort 14
spolien.titleInfo:
Date: from 1618
Material: Sandstone

Between 1616 and 1618, the lawyer Vincent Moller vom Baum purchased three plots of land on Speersort street in order to build a residential building with several storeys and a wide brick facade. The sandstone entrance portal was five-and-a-half metres high.
spolien.detailedInfo:
The portal came into the museum’s possession in 1910, when the former apartment building located on Speersort 14 had to be demolished in order to widen the street. When the museum was built, the portal was installed as the entrance to the garden terrace. The triangular gable is not originally part of the portal. The two columns feature cherubs, masks, and hanging fruit. Grotesque faces are depicted on the arch. The faces and the lion’s head in the centre of the arch may have been intended to function as gatekeepers.

Wealth and prosperity were to be protected here, clearly illustrated by the two allegorical figures holding cornucopias and grapes in the spandrels. In the 17th and 18th centuries, members of the nobility even resided in the building. Queen Christina of Sweden and Tsar Peter I were probably the most prominent visitors. Republican-minded citizens of Hamburg tended to tolerate such guests rather than expressing enthusiasm. Yet, it was convenient to have such representative premises in the city centre.

spolien.name: Busts of rulers and palm branches - Düsternstraße 43-51

thumbnails.thumbInfo: facade with palm branches and busts, 1916

spolien.titleInfo:
Date: ca. 1670
Material: Sandstone

The crossed palm branches on the south facade of the museum belonged to a stately home that was popularly nicknamed the Old Palace in Hamburg. It was built in the 1670s by the lawyer Joachim Schrötteringk.
spolien.detailedInfo:
The house was located in the southernmost part of what was then Neustädter Fuhlentwiete street, which is now called Düsternstraße. The symbol of the palm branch was fashionable in Hamburg during those decades and its biblical references familiar to most observers. The hope of peace symbolised by the palm branch was clearly appropriate for a time marked by repeated civil unrest.

Schrötteringk also chose the busts of four historic rulers for the facade of his residence. The busts portray, from left to right: the ancient rulers Ninus (with a full beard and a lion’s skin as a cloak), Cyrus the Great (with a turban), Alexander the Great (with long hair and a helmet), and Gaius Julius Caesar (with a laurel wreath). The succession of these rulers could symbolise the succession of historical power structures: The Assyrian Empire was followed by the Persian Empire, then the Macedonian Empire, and finally the Roman Empire. Ideally, this order could even be continued in the early modern period by the German Empire. It is conceivable that Schröteringk used this imagery to advocate stability in his native city, which the German Emperor was supposed to guarantee.

spolien.name: Portal Rödingsmarkt 60
spolien.titleInfo:
Date: 1631
Material: Sandstone

The town house at Rödingsmarkt 60 had already been standing for several decades when Dietrich Moller vom Baum inherited it in 1618 and he subsequently lived there until his death thirty years later. In 1631, he had a Renaissance portal added to the plain facade.
spolien.detailedInfo:
Since 1963, the portal has stood freely in front of the north side of the museum in the so-called ornamental garden. The arch originally included an entrance with five steps. These had been removed before the demolition of the residential building in 1896. The figurative decoration of the portal is quite striking. In the arch spandrels are two allegorical figures with several accessories. The figure on the left is holding eyeglasses and a mirror, while the figure on the right side holds a bird and ears of grain. These could be read as symbolising civic virtues, such as education and wisdom.

Educated contemporaries certainly knew how to translate the Latin saying in the cartouche above to the right: “HOMO / FINEM SUUM” (Man knows not his own end). The sword and scales as attributes of the female figure in the niche above the architrave are only preserved in remnants. This allegory of justice and the inscription “GLORIA IN EXCELSIS DEO” (Glory to God in the highest) above it were fitting for the work of councillor Dietrich Moller vom Baum. He also held the office of jurat, a representative of the congregation, at the Church of Saint Peter in Hamburg. There, he was responsible for the administration of the church property.

spolien.name: South portal of the Church of Saint Peter

thumbnails.thumbInfo: The museum after the Second World War

spolien.titleInfo:
Date: 1603
Material: Sandstone

The former south portal of Saint Peter’s Church had been dismantled and removed from its original location after the Great Fire. It was later incorporated into the inner courtyard of the museum. The portal was lucky to survive at this location as well.
spolien.detailedInfo:
Evocative photos show the severe destruction caused by bomb attacks in 1941, which still had not yet been cleared after the end of the Second World War. This resulted in the loss, among other things, of the crest above the since reconstructed triangular pediment, which featured the figure of St. Peter followed by that of an angel. The two female figures in the spandrels have been preserved. They can be seen as personifications of faith and justice. The figurative decorations of the portal were crafted by the sculptor Georg Baumann. It also includes the statues of the four evangelists.

The original occasion for the installation of the portal was a festive church service attended by a royal visitor in the autumn of 1603. Christian IV of Denmark was in Hamburg for a promise of loyalty from the city in the form of a tribute. He had just become the father of a potential successor to the throne. The portal arch provided the powerful, but unloved guest a triumphal entrance into the church. Perhaps, however, the imagery of the portal was intended to suggest the sort of Christian virtues that a self-confident city expected from a ruler.

spolien.name: Portals from the Bauhof

thumbnails.thumbInfo: In front of the main gate, ca. 1867
Installed in the guild hall of the museum
Installed in the guild hall of the museum

spolien.titleInfo:
Date: 1675
Material: Oak / Sandstone

In 1675, a building yard stood on the site of the present day Deichtorplatz. It consisted of a large timber-framed edifice with four wings of different lengths around a large courtyard. The yard employed up to 400 craftsmen, who were responsible for public building projects and the maintenance of the city’s forification.
spolien.detailedInfo:
Access to the building yard was provided by three portals made of oak wood. Today, these are installed side by side in the elongated guild hall within the museum. The arch now standing in the centre was originally the entrance to the stable on the north side of the building yard, signified by the horses rising in the arch spandrels. The former west or main portal (in the guild hall on the left) as well as the south or canal portal (in the guild hall on the right) feature similarly designed allegorical female figures in the spandrels. They are equipped with the tools used at the time by architects and wood craftsmen. Also depicted are building types of the day - a palace in the then fashionable Dutch style as well as water and wind mills.

Prominent on all three portals are carvings of an empty shield under a sprawling helmet ornament. It is assumed that the Hamburg city coat of arms was displayed here, but was removed as a forbidden symbol of power during the years of the French occupation of the city. From 1847 onwards, the building yard was gradually demolished because it stood in the way of the extension of the Berlin railway station, newly built roads, and, ultimately, a new customs shed.

building.headline: Eimbecksches Haus

thumbnails.thumbInfo: Lithography by F. Meyer, prior to 1842

building.description:
Date: 1769-1771
	Destroyed: 1842

The building housed rooms for parties, meetings, and a wine cellar where Einbeck beer was served. The court was also located here for a few years. Constructed by master builder Johannes Kopp, the edifice was destroyed in the Great Fire of 1842.
building.creator: Johannes Kopp / Johann Wilhelm Manstadt

building.headline: Neuer Wandrahm 10

thumbnails.thumbInfo: After road elevation, photo Georg Koppmann, 1884

building.description:
Date: End of the 17th century           
Demolished: 1886

The residential building on Neuer Wandrahm street had a magnificent baroque facade. The residents displayed their wealth. When the road was elevated in 1869, half of the portal disappeared under asphalt. In 1886, the house was demolished for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district.
building.destruction: Demolished: 1886  for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district

building.headline: Neuer Wandrahm 17
building.description:
Date: ca. 1680           
Demolished: prior to 1888

The city palace once belonged to the Amsterdam merchant, physician, and anatomist Theodor Kerckring, who settled in Hamburg in 1678. It was built according to plans by the architect Philipp Vingboons and demolished in 1886 for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district.
building.destruction: Demolished: 1886  for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district

building.headline: Katharinenstraße 9
building.description:
Date: 1630/40          
	Destroyed: 1909

When Mayor Johann Anderson the Elder lived in the house, he commissioned a ceiling painting with a stucco frame, which glorified science and art. Anderson was scientifically active himself. He wrote a book about whaling in Greenland.
building.creator: Stuccowork: Carlo Enrico Brenno, after 1730 / Painting: Johann Moritz Riesenberger, 1716–1720

building.headline: Altstädter Neuer Weg 52
building.description:
Date: Mid-18th century	     
Demolished: before 1888

The town house had an open staircase with a forged balustrade. Its occupants possessed rank and status, as representative staircases were usually found in the palaces of the nobility. The house was demolished for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district.
building.destruction: Demolished: 1888  for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district

building.headline: Bauhof at Deichtor

thumbnails.thumbInfo: In front of the main gate, ca. 1867
Installed in the guild hall of the museum
Installed in the guild hall of the museum
Installed in the guild hall of the museum, photo, Stier

building.description:
Date: 1675           
	Demolished: from 1847

In 1675, a building yard stood on the site of the present day Deichtorplatz. The yard employed up to 400 craftsmen, who were responsible for public building projects and the maintenance of the city’s ramparts. The building yard was demolished from 1847 onwards for the construction of the Berlin railway station.
building.creator: Architect: Hans Hamelau

building.headline: Fischmarkt 5
building.description:
Date: 1765/66          
	Demolished: 1886

Guests entered the house through a magnificent portal, which was decorated with symbols of industriousness - bees and a beehive. In 1861, the sale of fish at the fish market was considered a nuisance and it was moved to the harbour. The house was later demolished.

building.headline: Große Reichenstraße 29-33
building.description:
Date: 1730/40          
Demolished: 1908

The house on Große Reichenstraße belonged to the banker Johann Friedrich Tönnies. The facade was completely built out of sandstone, which was unusual for Hamburg, where brick facades were preferred. Usually, only portals and facade ornaments were made of sandstone.

building.headline: Große Reichenstraße 37

thumbnails.thumbInfo: Next to the Afrikahaus building, photo 1906
First floor, photo by Georg Koppmann, 1908
Second floor, photo by Georg Koppmann, 1908
Peter Behrmann und Anna Catharina Rodenburg

building.description:
Date: 1742           
	Demolished: after 1908

In 1745, the councillor Peter Behrmann and his wife Anna Catharina Rotenburg bought the house on Große Reichenstraße.Their coat of arms - RB under a crown - decorated the entrance portal. As part of the redevelopment of the old city, the house was demolished after 1908.
building.user: Peter Behrmann and Anna Catharina Rotenburg

adress.Standort: Große Reichenstraße 49-51 - Heute: ca. Kreuzung Große Reichenstraße/Brodschrangen

building.headline: Cranzsches Haus Große Reichenstraße 49-51

thumbnails.thumbInfo: In Planten un Blomen by the museum

building.description:
Date: after 1617	    
Demolished: 1890

Jürgen Schrötteringk, a rich merchant, resided in the house. On account of the colour of its facade, it was known as the red house and in the 17th century it was considered to be haunted. Later, a music shop belonging to August Cranz moved in. In 1890, the building, now called Cranzsches Haus, was demolished.

adress.Standort: Kleine Reichenstraße 17-19- Heute: ca. Kleine Reichenstraße 2; keine Fleete mehr; Nähe Alter Fischmarkt

building.headline: Kleine Reichenstraße 17-19
building.description:
Date: 1635           
Demolished: 1889

The residential building was built on Kleine Reichenstraße in 1635. The facade was decorated with ornaments in a Renaissance style. In 1889, the house was demolished during the redevelopment of the old city. The double portal and a small stone sink were salvaged.

building.headline: Neuer Wall 72-74

thumbnails.thumbInfo: North side of the museum, photo by medvedev

building.description:
Date 1710/20	        
Demolished: ca. 1908

The nobility was not permitted to purchase property in Hamburg, however, it was possible through intermediaries. Count Gerhard von Dernath lived in the Palais am Neuen Wall when he stayed in Hamburg. He also owned the Hasselburg estate in Holstein.
building.user: Around 1900, the building housed an antiquarian bookshop and C. Kothe's Wintergarten restaurant.

building.headline: Neuer Wandrahm 9

thumbnails.thumbInfo: South side of the museum, photo jn

building.description:
Date: End of the 17th century	  
Demolished: 1886

A row of particularly representative houses based on models from the Netherlands stood on Neuer Wandrahm street. They were all demolished after 1886 for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district. At this time, the houses were mainly used as offices and warehouses.

building.headline: Old Town Hall at Trostbrücke

thumbnails.thumbInfo: Copperplate engraving by Diederich Lemkus, ca. 1700
1601, guild hall in the museum, photo by Stier
J.W.Manstadt 1772, north side of the museum

building.description:
Dates: ca. 1290 / 1601 / 1664 / 1772           
	Destroyed: 1842

The medieval town hall was expanded twice in the 17th century. In 1842, it was blown up to stop the Great Fire from spreading. The house of the Patriotic Society stands on the site today, while the town hall is located on Rathausplatz.

building.headline: Katharinenbrücke 4

thumbnails.thumbInfo: God’s blessing gained, all is obtained
To God alone be the glory
Acanthus, inner courtyard of the museum

building.description:
Date: ca. 1700	  
Demolished: 1907

Merchants who lived near St. Catherine’s Church could afford to decorate the facades of their homes with elaborate ornaments. The house near St. Catherine’s Church was demolished in 1907.

building.headline: Spinnhaus on the Alster

thumbnails.thumbInfo: With the workhouse and poorhouse, watercolour, 1835

building.description:
Date: 1666-1674	 
Destroyed: 1842

The Spinnhaus was a prison. As its name implies, the inmates mainly had to spin wool. It was built with money left by the city councillor Peter Rentzel in his will. The Spinnhaus was destroyed in the Great Fire of 1842.

building.headline: Church of Saint Peter

thumbnails.thumbInfo: Prior to the Great Fire, lithography, 1842
Damaged during the Second World War
Inner courtyard of museum, photo by Stier

building.description:
Dates: 14th century / 1844-1849	   
Destroyed: 1842

After the Great Fire, the medieval church was left almost completely destroyed. It was rebuilt in the Gothic style. The south portal, originally built in 1603, was salvaged from the ruins and later relocated to the inner courtyard of the museum.

building.headline: Rödingsmarkt 60

thumbnails.thumbInfo: North side of the museum, photo by Stier

building.description:
Dates: End of 16th century / 1631  	
Demolished: 1896

The town house on Rödingsmarkt 60 had already been standing for several decades when the lawyer Dietrich Moller vom Baum inherited it in 1618. In 1631, he added a Renaissance portal to the plain facade and had a figure of Justitia mounted. The house was demolished in 1896.

building.headline: Düsternstraße 43-51

thumbnails.thumbInfo: Facade with palm branches and busts, 1916
Alexander the Great, south side of the museum
Caesar, south side of the museum
Cyrus the Great,  south side of the museum
Ninus,  south side of the museum

building.description:
Date: ca. 1670


The stately home was popularly nicknamed the Old Palace. It was built by the lawyer Joachim Schrötteringk. Palm branches and the busts of ancient rulers on the facade indicated that the owner desired political stability.

building.headline: Speersort 14
building.description:
Date: from 1618	 
Demolished: 1910
   
The lawyer Vincent Moller vom Baum purchased three plots of land on Speersort street in order to build a residential building with several storeys and a wide brick facade. In 1910, it was demolished in order to widen the street.

building.headline: Neuer Wandrahm 14
building.description:
Date: End of the 17th century	 
Demolished: prior to 1888

The merchant house had a representative front building and a rear building that served as a storehouse. In addition to the magnificent portal, there were two entrances in the front house that led into the cellar. Each entrance was decorated with a lion’s head, one of which is now in the museum collection.
building.user: 1678 Johann Behrmann,  1754 Garlieb Amsinck, 1785 Joh. Adolph Schlüter, 1825 George Carpzow Gorissen

building.headline: Neuer Wandrahm 20

thumbnails.thumbInfo: On portal on the west side of the museum

building.description:
Date: End of the 17th century	 
Demolished: prior to 1888

It is not always possible to determine from which house a particular architectural remnant or decorative element originated. Two cherub heads on the portal of the house on Neuer Wandrahm 10 displayed at the museum probably originate from the merchant house on Neuer Wandrahm 20.

building.headline: Niedernstraße 16/Mohlenhof
building.description:
Date: First half of the 18th century
	Demolished: 1904

The house was part of the complex comprising the Schauenburg and Mohlen estate, which belonged to the King of Denmark. This is indicated by the crown in the arch of one of the portals, which came into possession of the museum. In 1768, the estate became the property of the city and was later sold.
building.destruction: Demolished: 1914, due to the redevelopment of the old town

building.headline: Neue Wandrahm 6

thumbnails.thumbInfo: Photo by Charles Fuchs, prior to 1868
On portal in Planten un Blomen

building.description:
Date: 1675/80	
Demolished: 1886

In the 17th century, Dutch people settled around Neuer Wandrahm. Their city palaces were modelled on buildings in Amsterdam and other Dutch cities. All the houses were demolished for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district. Individual architectural elements entered the museum collection.
building.creator: Johann Jacob Erasmus

building.headline: Main parsonage of St. James
building.description:
Date: 1757-1759	
Demolished: 1909

The main parsonage was located directly next to the Church of St. James and was rebuilt in the middle of the 18th century. In 1909, it was demolished to make way for the Rappolthaus and the newly planned Mönckebergstraße. Only the rococo portal was preserved.
building.creator: Nicolaus Dietrich Petersen

building.headline: Churchyard of St. James
building.description:
Date: Archway, 1678
Demolished: 1881

An archway led from Steinstraße to the churchyard, which encompassed St. James’ Church. The figures of the four evangelists on both sides of the archway were carved by the artist Christian Precht.
building.creator: Christian Precht

building.headline: Steinhöft 13

thumbnails.thumbInfo: with the new elevated railway bridge

building.description:
Date: ca. 1760	 
Demolished: 1921

The merchant house with a plain facade was located directly on the inner port of the city. Only the portal featured a sophisticated design. The house was demolished for the construction of the Slomanhaus office building in 1921.

building.headline: Poggenmühle 2
building.description:
Date: End of 17th century	
Demolished: 1906

The house was modernised in the middle of the 18th century and a representative portal was added. In 1906, it was demolished for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district. A window frame belongs to the museum collection.
building.destruction: Demolished: 1906  for the construction of the Speicherstadt warehouse district

building.headline: Steinstraße 74
building.description:
Date: 17th century	   
Demolished: ca. 1914

In the Gängeviertel quarter on Steinstraße, there were courtyards with narrow alleys behind the houses. A relief was attached to a window parapet in the rear building of Steinstraße 74. It portrays a man wearing a turban and antique armour.

building.headline: Teilfeld 41
building.description:
Date: 1750 (inscription plates)    
	Demolished: prior to 1910

It is not known what the residential building looked like. Only two inscription plates with a religious reference have been preserved. They commemorate the purchase and renovation of the house in 1750 and 1770. It was located in the later Neustadt redevelopment area.

building.headline: Hüxter 20
building.description:
Date: 1549

The coat of arms belonged to a house on Hüxter street. This street no longer exists. Today, Willy-Brandt-Straße runs along this route.

building.headline: Marienstraße/Kohlhöfen
building.description:
Date: 17th century

The corner house featured a relief with the winged lion of the evangelist Saint Mark. It came from “Saint Mark’s Square” to Kohlhöfen street. Markus Meyer, the captain of the citizen’s guard, gave a donation to the Church of St. Nicholas in 1632. In return, a square was to be named in his honour.

building.headline: Speersort/Domstraße
building.description:
Date: 1710 / 1722              
	Demolished: 1882

When Count and Imperial Baron Max Heinrich von Kurtzrock acquired the corner house in 1722, he placed his coat of arms there. The building was designed by the architect Nicolaus von Kuhn. It was demolished in 1882 for the construction of the Hamburger Nachrichten building.
building.creator: Nicolaus von Kuhn

building.headline: Hamburger Bank
building.description:
Date: 1825-1827	  
Destroyed: 1842

The Hamburger Bank on Neß  was located next to the city hall and was built according plans by the architect Jacob Heinrich Ludolff. The building was destroyed during the Great Fire. A stone with the Hamburg coat of arms was salvaged. Today, the Alte Bankhalle office building stands here.
building.creator: Jacob Heinrich Ludolff

building.headline: Neß 6
building.description:
Date: 1532 / 1549 	    
Destroyed: 1880

The Gothic merchant house was owned by the Moller family. In 1880, it was demolished in order to widen Neß street. A coat of arms stone of the Moller family and a staircase side panel with a mill wheel from 1532 and 1549 have been preserved.

building.headline: Großneumarkt 19/21
building.description:
Date: after 1698	   
Demolished: ca. 1900

The Sonnenberg family coat of arms was displayed on the gable of their large town house - a golden sun against a blue sky. The family had purchased the property in 1698. The house was demolished around 1900 and the north side of the grounds were redeveloped.

building.headline: Deichtor
building.description:
Date: 1673 	   
Demolished: 1828

The Deichtor gate was one of the city gates that was closed at night. An inscription plaque was installed on the building, which was constructed in 1673. It urged citizens to protect the freedom which their forefathers had won. In 1828, the old Deichtor gate was replaced by a new building.

building.headline: Mohlenhofstraße 14
building.description:
Date: 17th century / 1768
Demolished: ca. 1930 

The Hamburg city coat of arms was displayed above the gate in the inner courtyard of a half-timbered house. The house belonged to the Schauenburg Hof courtyard. In 1768, ownership was transferred from the King of Denmark to the City of Hamburg. Demolished for the redevelopment of the old city south of Steinstraße street.

building.headline: Große Drehbahn 43
building.description:
Date: End of 18th century	 
Demolished: 1913

After the demolition of the building, the portal of the house entered the museum collection and was installed on the ground floor. A printing shop had been operating in the house since the 1870s.

building.headline: Große Drehbahn 44
building.description:
Date: End of 18th century
Demolished: 1913

There were not only residential buildings in Große Drehbahn street. A concert hall and the lodge house of the Hamburg Freemasons were also located there. The portal of house number 44 resembles the portal of number 43.
